result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked family planning activities
result.description: To improve drug management at health facility level 68 health surveillance assistants and 30 pharmacy technicians were trained in Logistical Management information systems. These trainings have led to improved data management especially in reducing stock out levels in the service delivery points. It has also contributed to improvements in data accuracy on drugs and commodities which moved from about 60% to 90% currently. As part of systems strengthening for commodity management at central and regional levels, the CO engaged the Mauritius Institute for Health to integrate the CHANNEL and ACCPAC soft wares in Malawi for better data capture of drugs and commodities. For effective implementation, 20 health personnel from the Ministry of Health and the Central Medical Stores Trust were trained in the new integrated system of CHANNEL and ACCPAC. The CO also utilizes the Country Commodity manager (CCM) to determine commodity requirements that feed into the commodity plan. The CO continued to support distribution of commodities by Central Medical Stores (CMS) to service delivery points by paying the 5 percent handling fees. The major enabling factor is the availability of resources from DFID and Global Reproductive Health Commodity Security Trust Fund which has enabled the CO to contribute close to 70% commodity requirements for the nation. The major challenge is the delay in full deployment between ACCPAC and CHANNEL.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked family planning activities
result.description: In partnership with USAID, the CO participated in the Reality Check Model of Family planning method mix which was aimed at calculating the actual costs of family planning commodities versus the expected method mix of family planning methods with expectation of raising the current CPR from 42% to 60% by the year 2020. The country office further supported the development of District implementation plans for the 5 focus district using the SEED model of the reality check concept to estimate the required funding and quantities of commodities. A total of 30 health workers and 5 traditional authority chiefs were trained. The CO supported the training of health service providers on Long Acting Contraceptive methods especially implanon in the five focus districts. There is a political will to reposition family planning in the country as demonstrated by governments FP2020 London summit commitments. The challenge is that Faith Based health institutions which contribute to 30 percent of the facilities do not offer family planning methods.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked family planning activities
result.description: The CO engaged chiefs to sensitise their respective communities in modern family planning methods as a key strategy in the prevention of maternal morbidity and mortality.. Anecdotal information indicates that the chiefs sensitization meetings have led to increased patronage of the FP service delivery points by women and men of reproductive health age. This has also led to increased male involvement for accessing FP methods in the service delivery points. Health Surveillance assistants in the five focus districts have been engaged in promoting demand and improved access to contraceptive commodities especially pills, male and female condoms and depo-provera. The CO also supported demand creation for condoms through CONDOMIZE campaign in collaboration with UNFPA headquarters, Ministry of Youth and National AIDS Council. The campaigns attracted over 7000 young persons ( 65% male and 35% female) from the Universities of Mzuzu and College of Medicine, Kamuzu College of Nursing, Blantyre University. A total of 50,400 male condoms and 4,000 female condoms pieces were distributed during the event

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked family planning activities
result.description: The Country office in collaboration with other stakeholders in Family Planning advocated for an increase in budgetary allocation for the procurement of contraceptive commodities. This resulted in an increase in the government allocating from MK1 million in 2012 to MK26.1 million in 2013. The enabling factor is the political commitment from executive and legislative arms of government. The key challenge is that funding allocated by government is limited and commodity procurement is heavily dependent on donors.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked family planning activities
result.description: The Ministry of health LMIS data indicates that 90% of facilities had no stock outs of at least 3 modern family planning methods, with selective stock outs for some commodities. The 90 % of no stock outs was mainly for Depo-provera, combined oral pills, male and female condoms and implants. While the selective stock outs were mainly for emergency pills, IUCD and progesterone only pills. To enhance logistics management the CO supported LMIS training of 68 HSAs and 30 pharmacy technicians which resulted in improved LMIS reporting in terms of accuracy and timelines from 60 to 90 percent. For demand generation the CO utilized chiefs and Health Surveillance Assistants to reach the community for increased access to family planning commodities.In addition the CO carried out CONDOMIZE campaign.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked population dynamics activities
result.description: The CO oriented 44 development planners (36 males and 8 females in 8 districts of ( Nkhatabay, Mzimba, Rumphi in the North; Mangochi, Chiradzulu, Thyolo, Mwanza, Chikhwawa in the South) on with knowledge of integrating population issues in district plans and strategies. This was timely as the districts were finalizing development of their plans for submission to the Local Government in the middle of the year and led to opportunity to utilize census data which is disaggregated to small geographic locations. The process of implementing such plans are likely to take longer than envisioned. The district assembly are lacking continuous technical support from national counterparts as well as the internal capacity to coordinate plan from various sectors such as education, gender, youth and health. The CO plans to engage a consultant for an on-going process of integrating population dynamics in district development plans.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked population dynamics activities
result.description: Following the technical and financial support towards the revision of the National Population Policy in 2012, the CO engaged various stakeholders in 6 successive advocacy meetings on the national population policy which was subsequently finalized in line with guidelines of the international development frameworks such as the ICPD beyond 2014, the MDGs and African Unions 2006 Maputo Action plan for Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights. The policy was approved by parliament and launched on 25th March 2013. The policy has provided a conducive environment for prioritization, coordination and implementation of Country population programmes and related interventions. Although aspects of the population policy are now being implemented, the CO will support a consultant to finalize the action plan for effective implementation. The CO supported the Malawi delegation to participate in the African Regional conference on ICPD beyond 2014, where in their capacity as chair, they made a statement on behalf of SADC pledging support and commitment in advancing population and development issues in the region.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked population dynamics activities
result.description: Two key staff from the National Statistical Office and one UNFPA programme officer participated in a study tour to Statistics South Africa. The tour has assisted in capacity building of staff involved in preparation for the development of 2018 census mapping strategy. The team learnt new technologies used in Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and have coordinated the development of a draft report on Social Atlas and Poverty. The report aims to highlight the linkage of population variables, sustainable development in the context of high fertility rates and unmet need for family planning. Two participants, one from National Statistics Office (NSO) (female) and one Male from CO, participated at the regional workshop on The establishment, maintenance and use of functional Web-based integrated management information systems (IMIS). At the end of the workshop, the Malawi team was able to familiarize with the system by covering such key steps such as installation of the software itself, creating data base in REDATAM form Malawi Population and Housing Census 2008 database, sorting and processing the census data, analysis, and indicator creation with the Process module. The web based system identifies remote areas where access to SRHR service is limited and would require UNFPA interventions. Malawi is among the remaining few countries in sub-Saharan Africa, whose REDATAM-based is not yet web based .The CO will support installation of the web based system. The NSO, as the strategic implementing partner, experienced significant transfer of staff such as the focal person on Malawi Social Economic Data Base, and Social Atlas management. The CO will advocate for the Ministry to get a replacement of the two focal persons.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked population dynamics activities
result.description: Two young people (male and female) were supported by the CO to participate at the ICPD beyond Africa Regional Conference on ICPD beyond 2014 held in September, Addis Ababa. The youth are spearheading advocacy on ICPD issues as demonstrated by their ability to engage in policy dialogue on early marriages and access to SRHR services

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked population dynamics activities
result.description: The CO spearheaded evidence based advocacy evidence that led to approval of national population policy and production of a draft of national population action plan. The capacity of districts to integrate population dynamics into district implementation plans was enhanced through training and technical support

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: The Midwifery Association of Malawi (AMAMI) has been supported with a post of Technical Advisor whose contribution to the organization is to strengthen the technical assistance provided to stakeholders in the country in midwifery. Through AMAMI, the UNFPA CO has supported the development of a draft of the first Midwifery strategy in the country for finalization in 2014. The CO also supported the Midwifery registration council to review and align the Midwifery scope of practice to ICM standards and developed the syllabi for direct entry into midwifery at technician and upgrading levels. After finalization, all these documents will enhance midwifery competencies of the trained and practicing midwives in the country. To improve availability of skilled attendants at birth, the CO supported twenty midwifery students with scholarships at University of Malawi to undertake the University Certificate in Midwifery course. Two additional students were supported with scholarships at Masters Degree level. The two students undergoing the masters degree progrmame are expected to mentor midwives in the five UNFPA focused districts on BEMONC skills that will improve the ability to save womens lives and thus contribute to reduction in maternal and neonatal mortality. The major challenge to midwifery programmes is the reluctance and lack of motivation among trained midwives to serve in hard to reach rural areas because of poor social infrastructure , lack of incentives and the limited government resources to implement the available midwifery programmes and meet expected standards. The major enabler to this is the political will from the executive and legislative arms of government

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: UNFPA supported 25 designated Basic emergency obstetric and neonatal care (BEmONC) health facilities in its five focus districts to improve their functionality in the delivery of the 7 signal functions expected of such sites. Specifically, support was provided to set up and improve the quality of care provided in high dependency units (HDUs) for treating emergency obstetric cases. A total of 50 service providers were oriented to manage obstetric emergencies. The CO procured equipment for the EmONC sites to facilitate delivery of quality obstetric care. The equipment comprised 100 Midwifery kits, 200 Sphygmomanometres and stethoscopes, 3000 gynaecological gloves. This has enhanced delivery of the 7 signal functions hence the increase in functionality of BEmONC sites. UNFPA also supported the quarterly supervision of the BEmONC sites to enable assessment of their level of compliance and ability to deliver the designated signal functions and save lives of women. The last supervision visit revealed that 100% of the BEmONC were able to deliver the signal functions and were therefore BEmONC compliant. The CO further addressed the major challenge of poor attitudes of midwives in the BEmONC sites through a national Trainer of trainers session on customer / respective care of patient in the fives focus district. The training has further reached over 300, service providers at different level in all the five districts. It is idwives and increase number of patients seeking for skilled attendants at birth in the facilities. The trainings were coupled with stakeholder meetings of availability of BEmONC facilities in the same districts.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: The CO supported the hosting of 2 fistula repair camps in 2013, resulting in the repair of 147 women. Additionally, equipment and supplies for fistula management (Fistula kits 1 and 2) were provided for 9 district and central hospitals. With these materials, the facilities successfully repaired an additional 107 fistula patients bringing the total number of women repaired in 2013 to 254, with a success rate of 85%. The successful repairs have facilitated the restoration of dignity and hope for affected women and reducing the fistula back-log. Two clinical officers completed the fistula repaired training in the country and an additional two Fistula clinician are currently being support to undertake an advanced degree in Obstetrics and Gynaecology to further enhance their skills. The combination of the training in fistula management and provision of equipment and supplies have resulted in increasing the capacity for fistula management in the country. The meeting of the fistula national task force was held to deliberate and provide guidance for fistula related activities in the country. The meeting resulted in enhanced coordination of fistula programmes in the country. The CO supported government to commemorate the first international fistula day that coincided with the first fistula camp. Fistula related media coverage and continued sensitization and awareness creation campaigns have continued throughout the area resulting in increased awareness of the issue and mobilization of affected women for repairs. Relevant gatekeepers have also become more aware of fistula prevention activities available. However, the major challenge remains limited interest among local surgeons to conduct routine repairs. UNFPA remains the major partner of the Malawi Government in Obstetrics Fistula programmes. Major facilitating factor include the partnership with DIRECT RELIEF from USA who provided fistula supplies.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: At national level, the CO has collaborated with government in building capacity of 80 national staff in MISP resulting in integrating MISP in district contingency plans which are presently being finalized. In response to disasters during the year, the CO provided both technical and material resources in forms of dignity and RH kits to affected areas to ameliorate suffering and ensure the restoration of dignity for affected population, especially women and girls. Specifically, technical support for provision of HIV prevention, delivery services and GBV was provided to the affected districts. In response to the call of government to strength the management of survivors of rape, the CO with support from ESARO built the capacity of 20 personnel in a TOT at the national level on the clinical management of rape victims. These officers are expected conduct further training at the district level which will improve the management of rape survivors. The CO has also supported the development of its own disaster contingency plan to support the existing national disaster contingency plan. The major enabling factor is that the Country developed its own contingency plan and the improved coordination of disaster management by Department of Disaster Management Affairs.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: The CO supported enhancement of midwifery skills in the country through the provision of scholarships and revision of the syllabus to meet the ICM standards. The CO also supported 25 health facilities to be BEMONC compliant. As at the end of the year all 25 health facilities (100%) meet the standards and are able to save lives of women from the major cause of maternal mortality. The country office supported the repair of 254 fistula patients, provided equipment and supplies to 9 health facilities and trained two clinicians in fistula management. These activities have improved capacity in fistula managements and restored dignity and hope for the repaired women. The capacity for the country to implement MISP was enhanced through training of 80 persons and development of the CO contingency plan in support of the national contingency plan.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: Using traditional leaders and community health workers for targeted mobilization of fistula patients in one of UNFPA focus district, Dedza has resulted in restoring dignity to 20 women in one year. Dedza district has in the past 3 years not referred women with obstetric fistula for repair on basis that there were not reporting in the health facility. However, Dedza district has been reporting high maternal deaths over the years and were able to identify the areas contributing to the high maternal death. With only U$1000 budget invested in sensitization meetings targeting the identified areas with high maternal deaths rates, a change was recorded. Specifically, advocacy meetings were held with chiefs and orientation sessions were conducted for the frontline health workers (health surveillance assistance) who further sensitized communities of Obstetric Fistula and availability of repair services. These resulted in mobilizing 40 patients for treatment. Out of the 40, 22 were repaired and other treated with conservative treatment. 91% of the repaired patients are dry and enjoying a normal dignified life.

This Programme Criticality level determination would then be used in the Acceptable Risk Model to ensure that UN personnel do not take unnecessary risk and that those who remain in-country work on highest priority activities in accordance with UN strategic results.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core hiv and sexually transmitted infection prevention services activities
result.description: The CO participated in the review of the National HIV policy, National strategic Framework and Condom Strategy and ensured that SRHR/HIV issues are integrated. The CO continued to support integration of SRHR /HIV services in 15 Health Facilities located in three of the five focus districts. In these facilities SRHR (including family planning) and HIV services are integrated in all the consultation areas. Capacity strengthening for the health workers in all the implementing facilities was done through the following activities: - Learning visits to FPAM Integra implementing clinics and orientation of 60 managers from all the three districts. This has strengthened the understanding, knowledge and skills for integrated services. As part of visibility of the SRH/HIV linkages project, door posters on intergrade services were produced for all the 15 facilities. This increased awareness among surrounding communities for the services being provided at each facility. The integration of services has led to reduced stigma and increased uptake of SRHR and HIV services.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core hiv and sexually transmitted infection prevention services activities
result.description: The CO provided technical and financial support for the establishment of the national network of adolescents living with HIV. This led to the creation an enabling environment for adolescent boys and girls to be able to engage in designing, implementation and monitoring of programmes addressing SRHR and HIV needs of young people in a coordinated manner. The CO also provided technical and financial support to increase the number of teen clubs for adolescents living with HIV from one in 2012 to 25. As a result, 2800 adolescent boys and 1430 girls living with HIV accessed SRHR/HIV services in a non-discriminatory and conducive environment compared to 498 (370 boys; 128 girls) in 2012. Following the successful establishment of the national sex workers alliance in 2012, thirty members of the national sex work alliance acquired a range of skills in 2013 through UNFPA supported training programmes on leadership and peer education. The trainings have enhanced sex workers organizational skills resulting in the alliance forming district networks in Mchinji, Nkhata Bay and Dedza. As a result, there has been improved working relationship with the Malawi Police Service. Examples of this improved relationship include reduction in arrests of sex workers. The key facilitating factor is the existence favourable policy environment for young people and HIV. However, the major constraint in strengthening capacity of adolescents living with HIV include wide spread stigma and discrimination of not only adolescents living with HIV but people living with HIV in general. The CO continues to address this challenge through its mass media programmes and partnerships with religious leaders and Faith Based Organizations which also address issues of stigma and discrimination.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core hiv and sexually transmitted infection prevention services activities
result.description: The CO continued to support HIV and STI prevention through mass media programmes targeting both key and the general populations in addressing issues of multiple concurrent partnerships (one of the key drivers of the HIV epidemic in Malawi). Thirty (30) radio programs and 21 TV programs on sexual and reproductive health, HIV prevention, gender and family planning were produced and aired. UNFPA also supported HIV interventions with Malawi Police Services. Two hundred and fifty (250: Men=167, Women=83) police officers and 140 couples were trained and oriented on SRHR/HIV, gender, family planning interventions. As a result of these interventions, condom uptake among the police increased from 12,000 male condoms in 2012 to 96,000 male condoms in 2013 at the national police headquarters alone. Over 27,280 Condoms have been distributed in bars among Female Sex Workers and their clients in two focus districts.The inclusion of issues of sex work in the HIV/AIDS policy provides a favorable environment for sex work interventions. Challenges include widespread condemnation of sex work as an immoral practice.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core hiv and sexually transmitted infection prevention services activities
result.description: The CO is currently implementing step 8 of the 10 Strategic Steps of the Comprehensive Condom programming on creating and sustaining demand for Condoms following successful implementation of the 7 steps of the framework. Following the Demand Generation Workshop for Condom utilization in 2012, the CO in collaboration with the Ministries of Health and Youth supported the CONDOMIZE campaign targeting University students on correct and consistent use of male and female condoms. Furthermore, the campaign aimed at addressing stigma associated with condom use among young people. Over 7000 students (approximately 65% males and 35% females) attended the sessions where 50,400 pieces of male and 4000 female condoms were distributed. The campaign has already led to increased uptake of male and female condoms by young people in strategic condom distribution points in two major cities (Blantyre and Mzuzu). The CO also supported the AFRIYAN youth network to develop communication materials on correct and consistent utilisation of male and female condoms by young people in Malawi. This has contributed to increased demand for condoms by young people in youth drop in centres as evidenced by the increase in male condom consumption rate from 35% in 2012 to 70% in 2013.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core hiv and sexually transmitted infection prevention services activities
result.description: The CO provided technical support for conducting an assessment of the linkages between SRH and HIV policies, systems, and service delivery through Family Planning Association of Malawi with financial support from EU. The assessment results assisted in determining pilot districts for implementing the SRHR/HIV linkages model in 15 selected districts for 3 years. The results also informed the model for the implementation of SRHR/HIV linkage in the 15 health facilities. The CONDOMIZE campaign was organized targeting youth in tertiary institutions as part of condom demand generation activities. Over 7,000 youth (65% male and 35% female) were reached. The CO supported establishment of one youth network and one sex workers alliance engaged in SRHR/HIV programmes for young people and sex workers

This Programme Criticality level determination would then be used in the Acceptable Risk Model to ensure that UN personnel do not take unnecessary risk and that those who remain in-country work on highest priority activities in accordance with UN strategic results.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: With technical and financial support from the CO, the national youth policy has been developed and launched and is currently being disseminated. During the reporting period, 85 (64female, 21male) YFHS service providers and 105 youth CBDAs were trained and this resulted into an increased number of adolescents aged 15-19 accessing SRH services especially family planning in the five focus district. Furthermore, Stop SRHR and gender based violence (SRHR GBV) campaigns were conducted through open days and 4,266 adolescents have been reached with messages and sensitized on the helpline for reporting cases of SRGBV. Fourteen (14) cases have been followed and 9 GBV cases have been concluded. UNFPA has further contributed to increased access to YFHS and during the reporting period, 1,976,000 young people have accessed YFHS (MOH YFHS report, 2013) The key enabling factor is the conducive policy environment for implementation of SRHR and related interventions targeting young people. The challenges include weak coordination of youth programmes at national level and inadequate capacity for implementation of youth programmes. The CO is supporting the Ministry of Youth and other related ministries for improved coordination and enhanced capacity for effective delivery of youth programmes.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: UNFPA in the joint programme implemented with UNICEF and WHO provided financial and technical support to implementing partners to provide educational scholarships to girls. The programme also focused on providing adolescents SRHR information and services as well as leadership skills training for girls. Subsequent to this, the school drop out rates have reduced from 51.3% in 2012 to 48% in 2013.. Mentorship of adolescent girls who had dropped out of school by mother support groups and girl guiders has led to reduced absenteeism and over 50 adolescent girls going back to school in 2013. The training of 170 (all female) SRH peer educators and 80 health care providers (51male, 29female) increased the number of adolescent girls accessing SRH information and services. A total of 1,264 adolescent girls have been reached with sexual and reproductive health rights information and 5,014 girls accessed YFHS. In addition, youth CBDAs provided condoms to 15,830 adolescents and pills to 1284 adolescents. The two Community Police Victim Support Units in the project areas have strengthened the protection systems for adolescent girls in the project areas as more GBV cases are being reported and charged. Ninety nine (99) girls only clubs are functional and their capacity in data collection and reporting has been strengthened through training. These continue to serve as safe spaces for adolescent girls to discuss SRH and developmental issues as well as promote girls leadership skills. The major enabler is favourable policy environment and political will. The major challenges include prevalence deep root harmful cultural practices including forced marriages which continue to violate rights of girls . The project is engaged in dialoguing with the media and community structures to modify harmful cultural practices that impact on adolescent girls.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: The CO implemented the cascade training to build capacity for implementation of SRHR programmes for adolescents in five focus districts. It also supported the provision of scholarships for adolescent girls and implementation of comprehensive SRHR information and services for girls in two districts under the adolescent girls programme.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: With technical and financial support from the CO, the national youth policy has been developed and launched and is currently being disseminated. During the reporting period, 85 (64female, 21male) YFHS service providers and 105 youth CBDAs were trained and this resulted into an increased number of adolescents aged 15-19 accessing SRH services especially family planning in the five focus district. Furthermore, Stop SRHR and gender based violence (SRHR GBV) campaigns were conducted through open days and 4,266 adolescents have been reached with messages and sensitized on the helpline for reporting cases of SRGBV. Fourteen (14) cases have been followed and 9 GBV cases have been concluded. UNFPA has further contributed to increased access to YFHS and during the reporting period, 1,976,000 young people have accessed YFHS (MOH YFHS report, 2013) The key enabling factor is the conducive policy environment for implementation of SRHR and related interventions targeting young people. The challenges include weak coordination of youth programmes at national level and inadequate capacity for implementation of youth programmes. The CO is supporting the Ministry of Youth and other related ministries for improved coordination and enhanced capacity for effective delivery of youth programmes.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: UNFPA in the joint programme implemented with UNICEF and WHO provided financial and technical support to implementing partners to provide educational scholarships to girls. The programme also focused on providing adolescents SRHR information and services as well as leadership skills training for girls. Subsequent to this, the school drop out rates have reduced from 51.3% in 2012 to 48% in 2013.. Mentorship of adolescent girls who had dropped out of school by mother support groups and girl guiders has led to reduced absenteeism and over 50 adolescent girls going back to school in 2013. The training of 170 (all female) SRH peer educators and 80 health care providers (51male, 29female) increased the number of adolescent girls accessing SRH information and services. A total of 1,264 adolescent girls have been reached with sexual and reproductive health rights information and 5,014 girls accessed YFHS. In addition, youth CBDAs provided condoms to 15,830 adolescents and pills to 1284 adolescents. The two Community Police Victim Support Units in the project areas have strengthened the protection systems for adolescent girls in the project areas as more GBV cases are being reported and charged. Ninety nine (99) girls only clubs are functional and their capacity in data collection and reporting has been strengthened through training. These continue to serve as safe spaces for adolescent girls to discuss SRH and developmental issues as well as promote girls leadership skills. The major enabler is favourable policy environment and political will. The major challenges include prevalence deep root harmful cultural practices including forced marriages which continue to violate rights of girls . The project is engaged in dialoguing with the media and community structures to modify harmful cultural practices that impact on adolescent girls.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: The CO implemented the cascade training to build capacity for implementation of SRHR programmes for adolescents in five focus districts. It also supported the provision of scholarships for adolescent girls and implementation of comprehensive SRHR information and services for girls in two districts under the adolescent girls programme.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core population dynamics activities
result.description: The CO oriented 44 development planners (36 males and 8 females in 8 districts of ( Nkhatabay, Mzimba, Rumphi in the North; Mangochi, Chiradzulu, Thyolo, Mwanza, Chikhwawa in the South) on with knowledge of integrating population issues in district plans and strategies. This was timely as the districts were finalizing development of their plans for submission to the Local Government in the middle of the year and led to opportunity to utilize census data which is disaggregated to small geographic locations. The process of implementing such plans are likely to take longer than envisioned. The district assembly are lacking continuous technical support from national counterparts as well as the internal capacity to coordinate plan from various sectors such as education, gender, youth and health. The CO plans to engage a consultant for an on-going process of integrating population dynamics in district development plans.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core population dynamics activities
result.description: Following the technical and financial support towards the revision of the National Population Policy in 2012, the CO engaged various stakeholders in 6 successive advocacy meetings on the national population policy which was subsequently finalized in line with guidelines of the international development frameworks such as the ICPD beyond 2014, the MDGs and African Unions 2006 Maputo Action plan for Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights. The policy was approved by parliament and launched on 25th March 2013. The policy has provided a conducive environment for prioritization, coordination and implementation of Country population programmes and related interventions. Although aspects of the population policy are now being implemented, the CO will support a consultant to finalize the action plan for effective implementation. The CO supported the Malawi delegation to participate in the African Regional conference on ICPD beyond 2014, where in their capacity as chair, they made a statement on behalf of SADC pledging support and commitment in advancing population and development issues in the region.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core population dynamics activities
result.description: Two key staff from the National Statistical Office and one UNFPA programme officer participated in a study tour to Statistics South Africa. The tour has assisted in capacity building of staff involved in preparation for the development of 2018 census mapping strategy. The team learnt new technologies used in Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and have coordinated the development of a draft report on Social Atlas and Poverty. The report aims to highlight the linkage of population variables, sustainable development in the context of high fertility rates and unmet need for family planning. Two participants, one from National Statistics Office (NSO) (female) and one Male from CO, participated at the regional workshop on The establishment, maintenance and use of functional Web-based integrated management information systems (IMIS). At the end of the workshop, the Malawi team was able to familiarize with the system by covering such key steps such as installation of the software itself, creating data base in REDATAM form Malawi Population and Housing Census 2008 database, sorting and processing the census data, analysis, and indicator creation with the Process module. The web based system identifies remote areas where access to SRHR service is limited and would require UNFPA interventions. Malawi is among the remaining few countries in sub-Saharan Africa, whose REDATAM-based is not yet web based .The CO will support installation of the web based system. The NSO, as the strategic implementing partner, experienced significant transfer of staff such as the focal person on Malawi Social Economic Data Base, and Social Atlas management. The CO will advocate for the Ministry to get a replacement of the two focal persons.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core population dynamics activities
result.description: Two young people (male and female) were supported by the CO to participate at the ICPD beyond Africa Regional Conference on ICPD beyond 2014 held in September, Addis Ababa. The youth are spearheading advocacy on ICPD issues as demonstrated by their ability to engage in policy dialogue on early marriages and access to SRHR services

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core population dynamics activities
result.description: The CO spearheaded evidence based advocacy evidence that led to approval of national population policy and production of a draft of national population action plan. The capacity of districts to integrate population dynamics into district implementation plans was enhanced through training and technical support

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core family planning activities
result.description: To improve drug management at health facility level 68 health surveillance assistants and 30 pharmacy technicians were trained in Logistical Management information systems. These trainings have led to improved data management especially in reducing stock out levels in the service delivery points. It has also contributed to improvements in data accuracy on drugs and commodities which moved from about 60% to 90% currently. As part of systems strengthening for commodity management at central and regional levels, the CO engaged the Mauritius Institute for Health to integrate the CHANNEL and ACCPAC soft wares in Malawi for better data capture of drugs and commodities. For effective implementation, 20 health personnel from the Ministry of Health and the Central Medical Stores Trust were trained in the new integrated system of CHANNEL and ACCPAC. The CO also utilizes the Country Commodity manager (CCM) to determine commodity requirements that feed into the commodity plan. The CO continued to support distribution of commodities by Central Medical Stores (CMS) to service delivery points by paying the 5 percent handling fees. The major enabling factor is the availability of resources from DFID and Global Reproductive Health Commodity Security Trust Fund which has enabled the CO to contribute close to 70% commodity requirements for the nation. The major challenge is the delay in full deployment between ACCPAC and CHANNEL.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core family planning activities
result.description: In partnership with USAID, the CO participated in the Reality Check Model of Family planning method mix which was aimed at calculating the actual costs of family planning commodities versus the expected method mix of family planning methods with expectation of raising the current CPR from 42% to 60% by the year 2020. The country office further supported the development of District implementation plans for the 5 focus district using the SEED model of the reality check concept to estimate the required funding and quantities of commodities. A total of 30 health workers and 5 traditional authority chiefs were trained. The CO supported the training of health service providers on Long Acting Contraceptive methods especially implanon in the five focus districts. There is a political will to reposition family planning in the country as demonstrated by governments FP2020 London summit commitments. The challenge is that Faith Based health institutions which contribute to 30 percent of the facilities do not offer family planning methods.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core family planning activities
result.description: The CO engaged chiefs to sensitise their respective communities in modern family planning methods as a key strategy in the prevention of maternal morbidity and mortality.. Anecdotal information indicates that the chiefs sensitization meetings have led to increased patronage of the FP service delivery points by women and men of reproductive health age. This has also led to increased male involvement for accessing FP methods in the service delivery points. Health Surveillance assistants in the five focus districts have been engaged in promoting demand and improved access to contraceptive commodities especially pills, male and female condoms and depo-provera. The CO also supported demand creation for condoms through CONDOMIZE campaign in collaboration with UNFPA headquarters, Ministry of Youth and National AIDS Council. The campaigns attracted over 7000 young persons ( 65% male and 35% female) from the Universities of Mzuzu and College of Medicine, Kamuzu College of Nursing, Blantyre University. A total of 50,400 male condoms and 4,000 female condoms pieces were distributed during the event

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core family planning activities
result.description: The Country office in collaboration with other stakeholders in Family Planning advocated for an increase in budgetary allocation for the procurement of contraceptive commodities. This resulted in an increase in the government allocating from MK1 million in 2012 to MK26.1 million in 2013. The enabling factor is the political commitment from executive and legislative arms of government. The key challenge is that funding allocated by government is limited and commodity procurement is heavily dependent on donors.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi core family planning activities
result.description: The Ministry of health LMIS data indicates that 90% of facilities had no stock outs of at least 3 modern family planning methods, with selective stock outs for some commodities. The 90 % of no stock outs was mainly for Depo-provera, combined oral pills, male and female condoms and implants. While the selective stock outs were mainly for emergency pills, IUCD and progesterone only pills. To enhance logistics management the CO supported LMIS training of 68 HSAs and 30 pharmacy technicians which resulted in improved LMIS reporting in terms of accuracy and timelines from 60 to 90 percent. For demand generation the CO utilized chiefs and Health Surveillance Assistants to reach the community for increased access to family planning commodities.In addition the CO carried out CONDOMIZE campaign.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: The Midwifery Association of Malawi (AMAMI) has been supported with a post of Technical Advisor whose contribution to the organization is to strengthen the technical assistance provided to stakeholders in the country in midwifery. Through AMAMI, the UNFPA CO has supported the development of a draft of the first Midwifery strategy in the country for finalization in 2014. The CO also supported the Midwifery registration council to review and align the Midwifery scope of practice to ICM standards and developed the syllabi for direct entry into midwifery at technician and upgrading levels. After finalization, all these documents will enhance midwifery competencies of the trained and practicing midwives in the country. To improve availability of skilled attendants at birth, the CO supported twenty midwifery students with scholarships at University of Malawi to undertake the University Certificate in Midwifery course. Two additional students were supported with scholarships at Masters Degree level. The two students undergoing the masters degree progrmame are expected to mentor midwives in the five UNFPA focused districts on BEMONC skills that will improve the ability to save womens lives and thus contribute to reduction in maternal and neonatal mortality. The major challenge to midwifery programmes is the reluctance and lack of motivation among trained midwives to serve in hard to reach rural areas because of poor social infrastructure , lack of incentives and the limited government resources to implement the available midwifery programmes and meet expected standards. The major enabler to this is the political will from the executive and legislative arms of government

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: UNFPA supported 25 designated Basic emergency obstetric and neonatal care (BEmONC) health facilities in its five focus districts to improve their functionality in the delivery of the 7 signal functions expected of such sites. Specifically, support was provided to set up and improve the quality of care provided in high dependency units (HDUs) for treating emergency obstetric cases. A total of 50 service providers were oriented to manage obstetric emergencies. The CO procured equipment for the EmONC sites to facilitate delivery of quality obstetric care. The equipment comprised 100 Midwifery kits, 200 Sphygmomanometres and stethoscopes, 3000 gynaecological gloves. This has enhanced delivery of the 7 signal functions hence the increase in functionality of BEmONC sites. UNFPA also supported the quarterly supervision of the BEmONC sites to enable assessment of their level of compliance and ability to deliver the designated signal functions and save lives of women. The last supervision visit revealed that 100% of the BEmONC were able to deliver the signal functions and were therefore BEmONC compliant. The CO further addressed the major challenge of poor attitudes of midwives in the BEmONC sites through a national Trainer of trainers session on customer / respective care of patient in the fives focus district. The training has further reached over 300, service providers at different level in all the five districts. It is idwives and increase number of patients seeking for skilled attendants at birth in the facilities. The trainings were coupled with stakeholder meetings of availability of BEmONC facilities in the same districts.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: The CO supported the hosting of 2 fistula repair camps in 2013, resulting in the repair of 147 women. Additionally, equipment and supplies for fistula management (Fistula kits 1 and 2) were provided for 9 district and central hospitals. With these materials, the facilities successfully repaired an additional 107 fistula patients bringing the total number of women repaired in 2013 to 254, with a success rate of 85%. The successful repairs have facilitated the restoration of dignity and hope for affected women and reducing the fistula back-log. Two clinical officers completed the fistula repaired training in the country and an additional two Fistula clinician are currently being support to undertake an advanced degree in Obstetrics and Gynaecology to further enhance their skills. The combination of the training in fistula management and provision of equipment and supplies have resulted in increasing the capacity for fistula management in the country. The meeting of the fistula national task force was held to deliberate and provide guidance for fistula related activities in the country. The meeting resulted in enhanced coordination of fistula programmes in the country. The CO supported government to commemorate the first international fistula day that coincided with the first fistula camp. Fistula related media coverage and continued sensitization and awareness creation campaigns have continued throughout the area resulting in increased awareness of the issue and mobilization of affected women for repairs. Relevant gatekeepers have also become more aware of fistula prevention activities available. However, the major challenge remains limited interest among local surgeons to conduct routine repairs. UNFPA remains the major partner of the Malawi Government in Obstetrics Fistula programmes. Major facilitating factor include the partnership with DIRECT RELIEF from USA who provided fistula supplies.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: At national level, the CO has collaborated with government in building capacity of 80 national staff in MISP resulting in integrating MISP in district contingency plans which are presently being finalized. In response to disasters during the year, the CO provided both technical and material resources in forms of dignity and RH kits to affected areas to ameliorate suffering and ensure the restoration of dignity for affected population, especially women and girls. Specifically, technical support for provision of HIV prevention, delivery services and GBV was provided to the affected districts. In response to the call of government to strength the management of survivors of rape, the CO with support from ESARO built the capacity of 20 personnel in a TOT at the national level on the clinical management of rape victims. These officers are expected conduct further training at the district level which will improve the management of rape survivors. The CO has also supported the development of its own disaster contingency plan to support the existing national disaster contingency plan. The major enabling factor is that the Country developed its own contingency plan and the improved coordination of disaster management by Department of Disaster Management Affairs.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: The CO supported enhancement of midwifery skills in the country through the provision of scholarships and revision of the syllabus to meet the ICM standards. The CO also supported 25 health facilities to be BEMONC compliant. As at the end of the year all 25 health facilities (100%) meet the standards and are able to save lives of women from the major cause of maternal mortality. The country office supported the repair of 254 fistula patients, provided equipment and supplies to 9 health facilities and trained two clinicians in fistula management. These activities have improved capacity in fistula managements and restored dignity and hope for the repaired women. The capacity for the country to implement MISP was enhanced through training of 80 persons and development of the CO contingency plan in support of the national contingency plan.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: Using traditional leaders and community health workers for targeted mobilization of fistula patients in one of UNFPA focus district, Dedza has resulted in restoring dignity to 20 women in one year. Dedza district has in the past 3 years not referred women with obstetric fistula for repair on basis that there were not reporting in the health facility. However, Dedza district has been reporting high maternal deaths over the years and were able to identify the areas contributing to the high maternal death. With only U$1000 budget invested in sensitization meetings targeting the identified areas with high maternal deaths rates, a change was recorded. Specifically, advocacy meetings were held with chiefs and orientation sessions were conducted for the frontline health workers (health surveillance assistance) who further sensitized communities of Obstetric Fistula and availability of repair services. These resulted in mobilizing 40 patients for treatment. Out of the 40, 22 were repaired and other treated with conservative treatment. 91% of the repaired patients are dry and enjoying a normal dignified life.

conditions.condition: The United Nations issues a criticality level for specific activities implemented within a given geographic location and timeframe. This Programme Criticality level determination would then be used in the Acceptable Risk Model to ensure that UN personnel do not take unnecessary risk and that those who remain in-country work on highest priority activities in accordance with UN strategic results.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked gender equality and reproductive rights activities
result.description: The CO collaborated with other UN Agencies to support advocacy with the legislative and executive arms of the government on the Gender Equality Act that resulted in Parliament approving the bill and the President assenting the bill in May 2013. This Act specifically focuses on the equality of women and adolescent girls in realising their rights and criminalises all harmful cultural practices that fuel GBV. The CO supported the Government to develop a Gender, Youth and Sports (GYS) Sector Strategy Plan which provides a framework for institutionalising and strengthening coordination in the sector. Seven (7) Technical Working Groups were established to operationalize the Strategy Plan and have been convening quarterly. To enhance national capacity for gender mainstreaming and analysis in selected sectors, the CO supported training of 81 Planners from Ministries of Transport, Finance and Agriculture to equip them with knowledge and skills to review and integrate gender in sector policies, budgets and plans. A study visit to Mozambique on Gender Equitable Local Development was supported for 14 planners and community leaders who have further trained over 100 women and girls in their districts. The have so far integrated identified gender specific needs in the 5 year district plans. An enabler is the gender sensitive Ministry of Finance Budgeting Guidelines and existence of the Gender Equality Act that commits the Government to prioritise allocation of resources for the promotion of gender equality. The major challenge is the lack of a mechanism to enforce adherence and capacity to mainstream gender in plans, policies and budgets. The CO will continue to build capacity of planners on gender mainstreaming and analysis.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked gender equality and reproductive rights activities
result.description: The CO supported the review of the Prevention of Domestic Violence Act (PDVA) to incorporate emerging issues and is being finalized. In order to increase the number of GBV cases prosecuted, 30 law enforcers in 13 districts were trained on the PDVA and gender related laws. In Mangochi 4 cases have already been prosecuted since October 2013. The CO supported a Gender Based Violence Survey which was conducted in 17 out the 28 districts of Malawi. The Study has provided evidence based data to inform GBV programming and is being utilised by stakeholders in Malawi. In order to provide comprehensive services to survivors of GBV, the CO sensitised 52 (30 males and 22 females) key stakeholders comprising of police, health and social welfare officers on One Stop Centres (OSCs) and GBV management. Resultantly 3 districts and 1 community OSCs are fully functional. To strengthen district coordination, planning, implementation and management of GBV, the CO supported the functionality of district based Gender Based Violence Technical Working Groups (GBV TWGs). The GBV TWGs in some selected districts like Chikwawa and Chiradzulu have followed up GBV reported cases for prosecution resulting in sentencing of 3 perpetrators. The CO supported the establishment of 28 women clubs, 54 youth clubs, and 70 Community Action Groups to handle, monitor, document GBV cases in 13 districts. The clubs discuss topical issues on GBV though community. 6 girls that experienced GBV in the form of sexual abuse and early marriages in Mchinji district reported their cases after listening to the community radio. The clubs will continue to follow up on prosecution of cases. An enabler is the political commitment to address GBV in the country. The major challenge is the limited space within the hospital premises to establish OSCs.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked gender equality and reproductive rights activities
result.description: The CO supported a baseline survey on socio-cultural practices impacting on the link between gender and HIV/AIDS including GBV. The study identified socio cultural practices in 13 districts. In partnership with community leaders dialogue meetings were organised to identify harmful practices and develop bye laws which have been approved by magistrate courts for operationalization in 2014. In one district (Salima), the Traditional Leaders have barred early marriages and parents that do not send children to school pay a fine to the community. About 60 Mother groups established with support from the CO clubs monitor girls to attend and remain in school. A total of 25 girls who were forced into early marriages have returned to school. There is political commitment at the highest level as evidenced by the establishment of Traditional Leader Committees by Her Excellency the President of Malawi to address socio cultural practices. A major challenge is the delay in the approval of the marriage and family relations bill that proposes to increase the marriage age from 16 to 18. The CO will continue to support lobbying of the legislative and executive arms of government in 2014 to approve the bill.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked gender equality and reproductive rights activities
result.description: The CO supported formation of 33men`s groups in each of the 13 impact districts. The groups will be trained on various topical gender issues as well as masculinity issues. Once trained, the men will be expected to be conducting men to men initiatives on combating GBV and HIV as well as any other issues that impinge on womens rights. The CO has continued to support Men for Gender Equality ( MEGEN) to mount a GBV travelling campaign during the 16 days of activism on ending violence against women and girls. The campaigns focused on strengthening the role of men as change agents to combat GBV. This has led to 4,224 GBV cases being reported in 2013 from the 10 districts where the campaigns were mounted. The major enabler is that the Men for Gender Equality is well-established Network that provides a conducive environment for men to engage in activities to end GBV. A key challenge is the entrenched negative socio- cultural practices in the country. The CO will continue to train men to demystify gender misconceptions and myths.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Malawi earmarked gender equality and reproductive rights activities
result.description: The CO supported the finalization of the Gender Equality Act which has provided a conducive legal environment for protection of womens rights. Further, the CO has supported the establishment and functionality of 7 Gender, Youth and Sports Technical Working Groups to facilitate implementation of national policies such as the recently approved Gender Equality Act. The CO has also supported the Ministry of Transport in gender responsive budgeting to ensure that national sector plans and budgets address needs of women, men, boys and girls. In an effort to build capacity for programming of GBV in humanitarian settings, the CO trained 72 people (60 females and 12 males) in clinical management for physical and sexual assault and media in humanitarian response.
